I agree with you that in an ideal world politicians should not compromise on their principles. But the reality is, a man (or woman) who remains true to their principles will not become a successful politician. A politician, by the nature of his job, must do a lot of compromising and sometimes this include their principles in order for them to be a successful one. Yes there will be some example of an exception to this but in this current world it is 99% like that.If I follow your suggestion an enter politics, most probably I will not become a successful politican because I WILL NOT compromise my principles. Hope clearer now.   Madey made you pay toll & electricity to his crony everyday, and probably your children and grandchildren too.Madey made you owe the banks up to 9 years in loans to pay for crappy cars so his pet project can be (un)successful (one of many projects btw most of which are failures)Madey made you lose faith in almost all the nation's institutions until now Bijan can use it like his personal staffMadey 'allegedly' made you some additional fellow citizens in SabahMadey MADE Bijan happens (so indirectly Madey made you pay for that berkin and diamond too).The above are only some things this guy Madey (whoever he is) made. I can list more but I don't want to go into specifics for the obvious potential legal complications as this is a public forum.

I'd have to disagree, you need someone who has good principles and wont budge on it unless the manority of the rakyat requests for a change. All the pm we had are ones with bad principles.Meanwhile for ph, some of them had good principles but had to compromise to accommodate other ph members and see where it got them now. You need a dueterte here, he stated his principles during his campaign which is to battle drugs and sticked to it despite all the foreign criticism and a small number of criticism from some of the locals who clams their family members were wrongly persecuted. He still didn't budge on his principles because the majority of Filipinos who voted him to eradicate drug problems there wanted him to continue on. If he compromised due to the few people who claimed to be wrongly persecuted, he would have betrayed the trust of the majority who voted for him. We need a leader who meets the need of the majority, not the minority.

Yes I give up. Whatever happens happens. Moronic Malaysians deserve their government whichever it is.Seriously, you seem to see these politicians as people that can be trusted. I don't. The vast majority of politicians are only looking out for NO. 1. Previously, I am able to vote for opposition parties even if they are not perfect because of course there are NO perfect political parties. They are just a group of normal tom, dick and harry just like you and me with all their quirks and foibles. Any group of people, no matter how noble their purported cause is can be turned and there is a reason 'power corrupts' is a saying. The only guard against any political parties abuse of power is the check and balances in the various national institutions. Once this is compromised, the country is more or less doomed.Now who almost single-handedly systematically destroyed the various institutions that are supposed to guard us during his twenty odd years in power? Yeah the guy who is now the leader of the political party you seem to have put your whole trust in. You might think the other members of PH can check this man, but looking at the historical record of the almost comical decisions and actions of most of them, I have no confidence. With what this man has done to this country, I am truly disappointed that the other PH leaders can work with him, much less make him their leader. I am not surprised though, since as I have noted above - most politicians only look out for No. 1.You can go ahead and trust their manifestos and plans, whatever. To me it is not worth the paper they're written on. Benteras corruption to akar umbi? You think that man will let that happen? I laugh.Nevertheless, I will be more than happy should I be proven wrong. In fact I pray that I am. But don't tell me to vote for that traitor.

The main reason is that theres lots of other people more senior than him who wants the post. He doesnt have his own independent supporter base yet to push him without relying on someone elses camp.The other reason is that he kinda needs to decide whether he wants to be a populist or he wants to be technical. We all know hes being pushed as the econs expert - but the thing is, populist initiatives tend to make little economic sense. Either youre a boring (but correct) econ, or you kinda get called out on your statements - which makes people who know the stuff question your competence. Gaffes like langkah kajang do not help.Still, most people dont know much about the stuff so no ones the wiser, but I believe this must be one of the reasons why you dont see tony pua saying these things anymore.

The concern about 'win first' isnt about it not being possible, but the fact that the win is tenuous. If the margin is razor thin, absolutely nothing stops a party from threatening to join the other side. Pas can demand for the hudud law to be passed, or mahathir can demand for mukhriz to be in the top post. Whichever side takes up the offer gets to be government.
